examples.title: Career Advancement Goal
examples.description: Achieve a promotion to Senior Manager position by Q3 2025 by completing leadership certification, leading 2 cross-functional projects, and receiving 'exceeds expectations' in annual performance review, resulting in 15% salary increase and expanded team management responsibilities.

examples.title: Health & Wellness Goal
examples.description: Run a half-marathon (13.1 miles) in under 2 hours by October 2025 by following a 16-week training plan, running 4 times weekly with progressive mileage increases, cross-training twice weekly, and tracking performance using a running app to build endurance and achieve a personal fitness milestone.

examples.title: Financial Goal
examples.description: Save $15,000 for home down payment by December 31, 2025, by automatically transferring $1,250 monthly to dedicated savings account, reducing entertainment spending by 30%, earning extra $200 monthly through freelance work, and reviewing budget progress every two weeks to achieve homeownership goal.

howToWrite.title: Specific
howToWrite.description: Don't say "get healthier" — say "lose 15 pounds" or "run a 5K." The more specific your goal, the clearer your path forward. Vague goals create vague results.

howToWrite.title: Measurable
howToWrite.description: If you can't measure it, you can't track it. Use numbers: pounds lost, revenue earned, hours studied. Ask yourself: how will I know when I've actually achieved this?

howToWrite.title: Achievable
howToWrite.description: Challenge yourself, but stay realistic. Can you actually do this with your current time, money, and skills? Stretch goals are great — impossible goals just lead to burnout.

howToWrite.title: Relevant
howToWrite.description: Does this goal actually matter to you, or are you doing it because you think you "should"? If it doesn't align with your real priorities, you won't stick with it.

howToWrite.title: Time-bound
howToWrite.description: "Someday" never comes. Set a real deadline. For bigger goals, break them into monthly milestones so you can catch problems early and stay on track.

faq.question: What does SMART stand for in goal setting?
faq.answer: SMART stands for Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. It's a framework from 1981 that gives you clear criteria for setting goals that actually work. Instead of saying "I want to get fit," you'd say "I'll run a 5K in under 30 minutes by June." Much clearer, right?

faq.question: How often should I review my SMART goals?
faq.answer: Depends on the goal. For short-term stuff (under 3 months), check in weekly. For bigger goals, a quick weekly check plus a deeper monthly review works well. The key is consistency — pick a day and stick to it. Sunday evenings work great for most people.

faq.question: Can I change my SMART goals once I've set them?
faq.answer: Absolutely. If something's not working after 4-6 weeks, adjust it. Life changes, priorities shift. Just don't change goals every other day — that's procrastination in disguise. Quarterly reviews are a good rhythm for major adjustments.
